subject: Law
title: Cybersecurity and International Norms
description: A short lesson to help you apply Cybersecurity and International Norms.

hook.text: A state-sponsored cyberattack shuts down a hospital. Is that an act of war? International law has no clear answer.

buildup.text: No binding treaty governs cyberwarfare. States are developing voluntary norms through the UN and regional bodies.

discovery.text: The Tallinn Manual applies existing international law to cyber operationsâ€”but it's advisory, not binding.

twist.text: Attribution is the core problem. Proving which state launched an attack is technically hard and politically charged.

climax.text: States agree that international law applies in cyberspace. They disagree on exactly how.

punchline.text: The weapons are digital. The legal framework is still analog.

quiz.question: What is the Tallinn Manual?
options: A non-binding guide applying international law to cyber operations
